Introduction

All staff working within Maternity Services has a role in identifying and ensuring that unborn and children are protected from harm. Maternity staff are likely to have significant contact with families who may require support and interventions in relation to safeguarding. All Maternity staff need to be aware of national and local procedures and their responsibility in relation to these. Staff need to recognise that the pregnant woman herself can be vulnerable and may require an adult Socail Crae referral in her own right.
Scope
This policy sets out the key principles that all staff and workers working across MSE should be complying with safeguarding children, young people and adults at risk of harm or abuse.

This policy applies to all employees and workers of the MSE group, including seconders into and out of the organisation, volunteers, students, honorary appointees, trainees, contractors, and temporary workers, including locum doctors and those working on a bank or agency contract.
For ease of reference, all employees and workers who fall under these groups will be uniformly referred to as “staff” in this document.

This policy applies to all areas within the MSE Hospitals Group for which children and young people under the age of  years receive appointments and to any instances when a child/young person is not brought to an appointment/does not attend appointment OR whose appointment is cancelled by their parent/carer.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
/ In-house Safeguarding Board Meetings monitor compliance with Safeguarding, children policies and processes.
4.1.1 Site Safeguarding Children Committees / Operational meetings oversee all operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies.

4.1.2 The Group Integrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee is a strategic meeting to check and challenge that MSE systems and processes are fit for purpose to safeguard vulnerable individuals, focus on all services but not be operational, oversee CQC requirements and facilitate discussion relating to external strategic issues that may impact on the MSE group.
Chief Executive as Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust.
4.2.1 Chief Nurse / Chief Medical Officer will be corporately responsible for the implementation of this policy. This includes:
When the policy is reviewed and updated incorporating the time frame for the
process to be undertaken;
Reporting into the necessary governance committees;
Ensuring that MSE provides/supports the training for staff to discharge their
responsibilities and that there is an appropriate competency framework to
support this.
4.2.2 The Director of Nursing at SUHT also holds the executive lead in relation to Safeguarding Children.

4.2.3 Associate Directors of Nursing/Head of Midwifery/Matrons/Heads of Departments/Service Managers/Department Managers are responsible for the implementation of this policy at department level. This includes identifying training needs and ensuring staff attend training; assessing service requirements against what the service is delivering.
(Refer to Child Safeguarding Policy / MSEPO-19010)

4.2.4 Designated, Named Professionals and the Safeguarding Team lead personnel have a key role in championing the importance of safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children throughout the MSE group.
4.2.5 MSE Safeguarding Teams:
Designated doctor;
Named doctor;
Group named nurse, safeguarding children;
Group named midwife, safeguarding children;
Specialist nurses, safeguarding children;
Specialist safeguarding midwives;
Group Associate Director and Deputy Director Safeguarding.
4.2.6 Other professionals who are able to provide advice and information in relation specifically to safeguarding issues are:
Paediatric Liaison Health Visitor;
Head of Paediatrics;
Head of Midwifery.
4.2.7 In the absence of the above professional, advice can be sought from senior
paediatric professionals; on-call paediatric registrar and on-call Paediatrician for Child Protection via switchboard and, in addition, advice can be sought by the
relevant Social Care Department.
4.2.8 Duties of all MSE staff (substantive or non-substantive, including volunteers) must be aware of and adhere to the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Safeguarding procedures.
Safeguarding is each individual employee's responsibility as set out in Working
Together to Safeguarding Children (2018) and the Southend, Essex and Thurrock (SET) Interagency Child Protection and Safeguarding Procedures (2019).

“All those who come into contact with children and families in their everyday work, including people who do not have a specific role in relation to child protection, have a duty to safeguard and promote the welfare of children” (What To Do If You Are Worried A Child Is Being Abused 2006).
4.2.9 Specifically all Trust staff must:
Participate in training on how to safeguard and promote the welfare of children;
Be alert to potential indicators of abuse or neglect in children;
Work effectively and liaise with professionals within the Trust and other partner
agencies;
Remain professionally updated regarding safeguarding issues;
Work within the guidance from their relevant professional regulatory body.
(Refer to Child Safeguarding Policy / MSEPO-19010)
Trust staff members who work predominantly or completely with adults who have
parental responsibilities share a commitment to safeguard and promote the
welfare of the child.
4.2.10 Duties of Clinical Bank and Agency Staff Working for the Trust

The MSE group is committed to professionally developing clinical bank and agency staff to take an active professional role in child protection. This development is facilitated through training and regular supervision:
Staff are expected to work within safe parameters and the NMC Code of
Conduct;
To liaise with the appropriate agencies in the identification of suspected
physical abuse, sexual abuse, emotional abuse and neglect and the
assessment of children in need;
Bank and agency staff must work to the Trust's policies and procedures.
It is also the responsibility of the practitioner to professionally update on child
protection issues and to attend mandatory and relevant study days.

4.2.11 Managers and Team Leaders will be responsible for monitoring the actions of their staff to safeguard and promote the welfare of children via access to supervision and personal development reviews. Children will be listened to appropriately and concerns expressed about their or any other child's welfare are taken seriously and responded to in an appropriate manner.
Maternity safeguarding Process
Booking Interview

The purpose of the booking interview in relation to safeguarding children is to undertake an initial assessment using the relevant framework for assessment. At booking an assessment of the woman's individual needs including a social history is obtained to ensure she receives appropriate care. During the booking the pregnant woman will be asked questions that may highlight risk a few of them are in regard to Mental Health, use of drugs or alcohol, current or previous Social Care and Domestic Abuse.The full demographics of the father of the baby and any other children of either parent needs to be obtained. At the booking interview women will be informed of the routine requirement to share information with other health professionals in order to assess the needs of the woman and her family.
Identifying the Risk of Harm

Where the midwife becomes aware of safeguarding concerns and/or vulnerability a referral to social care needs to be considered in line with the SET procedures 2019. It is essential that the referral is comprehensively completed and highlight all concerns in regard to the family Social Care will asess the referral and if it

meets their criteria will open a case. Social Care will then complete necessary assessments and arrange meetings that may be required. SET procedures states that referral should be made on the unborn/ new born for the follwing reasons. It must be highlighted that the reasons must be used as a guide but is not exhaustive list:
A parent or other adult in the household, or regular visitor, has been identified as posing a risk to children;
A sibling or child in the household is subject of a child protection plan;
A sibling or child has previously been removed from the household either temporarily or by court order;
There are significant domestic abuse issues (Safeguarding children affected by domestic abuse and violence);
The degree of parental substance misuse is likely to impact significantly on the baby's safety or development;
The degree of parental mental illness/impairment is likely to impact significantly on the baby's safety or development;
There are significant concerns about parental ability to self-care and/or to care for the child e.g. unsupported, young or learning disabled mother;
Any other concern exists that the baby may be at risk of significant harm including a parent previously suspected of fabricating or inducing illness in a child or harming a child;
A child aged under 16 at the time of conception, is found to be pregnant;
There has been a previous unexpected or unexplained death of a child whilst in the care of either parent;

There are maternal risk factors e.g. denial of pregnancy, avoidance of antenatal care (failed appointments), non-cooperation with necessary services, non-compliance with treatment with potentially detrimental effects for the unborn baby.
Making a referral to Children's Services

Referrals should be made in a timely manner. Southend Social care will accept referrals from  weeks gestation; Essex social care will accept referral at the point of presentation. Thurrock will accept referral if just in regard to the unborn at 20-22 weeks gestation, but will accept sooner if complex.
5.3.1 Any member of staff can make a referral in respect of an unborn baby, the individual that raises the concerns should make the referral.

5.3.2 Wherever possible, parents should be informed of the decision to make a referral to Children's Services, if they have not been informed. This and the reason why must be highlighted within the referral.Referrals should be made using the relevant form dependant on the area the woman resides in. All forms are found on hospital intranet.

5.3.3 The referral should be copied to the Safeguarding Midwife. Referrals to social services must include as much information as possible regarding the woman, her family and the specific concerns in relation to safeguarding children and vulnerabilities. This includes the expected delivery date of the unborn.
5.3.4 If you are not sure if it is appropriate to make a referral you should:
Discuss with the Safeguarding midwife / Safeguarding Team;
Children's Social Care can be contacted by telephone for information sharing to support possible referral;
Consider contacting other professionals involved with the family, i.e. health visitor / GP;
In case of a born baby, discuss with the paediatric consultant on call.

5.3.5 If you decide not to refer, reassess your decision the next time you see the woman and document the rational for your decision at this time. This can then be discussed in safeguarding supervision.
Responsibilities for Safeguarding
The responsibility for the overall care of the woman and her family is with the

allocated Community Midwife or case holder. They are responsible for ensuring robust communication with their team colleagues so that all team members are aware of concerns in regard to families within their area of practice. In addition, the allocated midwife must also ensure good communication with the Health Visiting Service and GP during the ante natal and post-natal period.

5.4.1 The allocated Community Midwife or case holder for the woman will be responsible for attending multi-agency meetings or ensure that a nominated colleague attends in her place. The nominated colleague MUST be provided with a full overview of the case and information that will need to be shared at the meeting.

5.4.2 All midwives are responsible for maintaining good record keeping. If there are multi agency professional differences which can not be resolved discuss them initially with Safeguarding Midwife who will provide support and guidance in regard to escalation process

5.4.3 Although a concern is often identified at booking, midwives are responsible for the on- going assessment of the woman throughout the pregnancy, labour and post- natal period. Concerns may be identified at any time and the individual identifying such concerns is responsible for initiating a case discussion with the Safeguarding and/or making a referral to Social Services. Where a midwife has concerns or suspects that there are safeguarding issues, early communication with Social Services is essential. Where appropriate, ensure that the Neonatal Unit is informed of specific concerns.
Domestic Abuse
All midwives are required to routinely ask every woman about domestic abuse at

least four times during the woman's maternity care. This is known as routine enquiry.This is in addition to an adopting a target approach where signs or indicators of domestic abuse are observed at any time throughout maternity services. If a woman discloses domestic abuse a DASH risk assessment form should be completed .See domestic abuse policy which can be found in the local intranet. DV1's are police reports on domestic abuse and are submitted to the Safeguarding midwife when information in regard to a pregnancy is highlighted. This is forwarded to the case holding/ community midwife who has a responsibility to contact the woman if the pregnancy is confirmed.
Safeguarding Meetings
5.6.1 Strategy Meetings

It is the midwives responsibility to attend strategies to give essential and often unknown information to assist with decision making. After attendance at this meeting the midwife MUST update the Maternity Safeguarding Team.
Child Protection Case Conference

When a decision is made to convene an initial child protection case conference it is the responsibility of the midwifery service to provide a midwife to attend the meeting. Wherever possible this should be the community midwife or case holder.
Case Conference Reports

Prior to attending a child protection case conference, the midwife will be required to provide a written report. This report summarises the midwive's involvement with the woman and her family during the pregnancy and/or the post-natal period. It will also include the midwives assessment of the parents' capacity to safeguard the child and promote their welfare. Where the author of the report is unsure whether to share information or not support and guidance can be sort from the safeguarding Midwife. Reports should be made available to the ‘conference chair' 48 hours before the conference. It is good practice for the midwife to share, discuss and explain their report with the families at least one day before the conference.  After attendance the midwife MUST update the Maternity Safegaurding Team.
Core Groups

The core group is responsible for developing and implementing the child protection plan. The key worker is usually the social worker and other members will include professionals with a specific involvement, including midwives. The core group should first meet within 10 working days of the case conference and the community midwife or case holding midwife for the woman should ensure that either she or a member of her team attends. After attendance the midwife MUST update the Maternity Safeguarding Team.
Other Safeguarding Meeting

Other meetings can include Child in Need and discharge planning meetings. Representation by a midwife at all of the aforementioned meetings is essential .The professional that calls the meeting is responsible for ensuring that all the appropriate professionals/agency are invited. When future dates are set at meetings it is the attending midwives responsibility to share this information appropriately
Birth Plan in regards to Safeguarding concerns
It is the Safeguarding Midwife's responsibility to ensure a post delivery plan is

available no later than 35 - 37 weeks gestation and made in conjuction with the Social Worker. This must be available to all clinical Maternity staff for guidance. All staff are responsible for accessing the plans and acting appropriately. Staff involved in the care of the woman during the birth and the post-natal period will be responsible for accurately documenting any concerns. This may later be required in the form of a report; for example a post birth conference or any care proceedings initiated by the Local Authority.
Safeguarding Children during the Postnatal Period
If a discharge planning meeting has been requested the ward mdiwife needs to
liaise with the Social Worker to arrange this.

5.11.1 It must also be recognised that during the postnatal period concerns can esculate the in level of concern, and this must be communicated to the Social Worker or the duty Social Wokrer if out of hours. It may result in a change in the plan.

5.11.2 If the mother and the baby are to be discharged home together, midwives working within the unit have the responsibility to ensure the appropriate community team of midwives are made aware of the risks and the ongoing care and support to maintain continuity. At each post-natal visit, midwives should observe, discuss and document capacity to parent and parenting ability. Prior to the new birth visit of the Health Visitor the appropriate documentation must be completed so that any update plans of care are communicated from the Midwifery to the Health Visiting Service.
Removal of the baby prior to leaving Hospital
When a decision is taken that a baby is not to go home with the parents, a birth plan needs to be in place that ensures clarity in regard to safeguarding
arrangements. Included in the plan should be:
An overview of the case highlighting the risk factors;
Contact number of social services/ named social worker/ emergency duty team for out of hours when the mother is admitted to hospital in established labour;
Contingency plans if the baby is born outside of hospital;
Arrangements for initiating legal proceedings;
Action for midwives to take in the event of the parents attempting to remove the baby from hospital;
Inclusion of a police incident or occurrence number where appropriate.
In highrisk cases the baby maybe removed from the parents care and placed within the Neonatal baby Unit during the mothers stay in hospital.
Training Requirements

Staff should have the knowledge and skills relevant to their area of practice to contribute to safeguarding children from harm. Staff working with children and families will be required to undertake level 1, 2 and 3 safeguarding training provided by MSE (The training should be in accordance with the Intercollegiate Document: 2019) as appropriate to the role they hold on the unit.
Safeguarding Supervision

Safeguarding supervision is essential for all midwives when dealing with safeguarding issues to ensure practitioners are competent, confident and well supported in their role in Safeguarding Children and the vulnerable pregnant woman in line with MSE Safeguarding Children Supervision Policy.
The following arrangements for safeguarding children supervision for midwives
are:

One to one supervision will be provided for Community, case holding and relevant specialist Midwives. This should be provided quarterly and it is the responsibility of the individual midwife to ensure that she accesses supervision from the maternity safeguarding team;
Group supervision every six months for unit midwives
It is the responsibility of the midwives and midwifery managers of each area to ensure supervision is maintained. Midwives must bring cases for discussion with safeguarding and vulnerability themes.
Information sharing

“There is nothing within the Caldicott report, the Data Protection Act 1998 or the Human Rights Act 1998, which should prevent the justifiable and lawful exchange of information for the protection of children.” (Carlisle Review, 2002)

Research and expertise show that keeping children safe from harm requires professionals and agencies to share information. Normally personal information should only be disclosed to third parties (including other agencies) with the consent of the subject of the information. Where there are concerns that a child is or maybe at risk of harm, the needs of the child must come first and consent may not be possible or necessary.

A Standard Operating Procedure for sharing information in pregnancy is in place for Midwifery, Health Visiting and GPs has been implemented across the local health economy and supported by the CCG to assist in the sharing of information between professionals. All midwives must be knowledgeable in the use of the process.

The HV communication form will be completed when vulnerabilities and /or safeguarding concerns are highlighted. This will be sent directly to the appropriate health vising teams and a copy sent to Safeguarding Team. This will then be put onto to patient's electronic records.
GP's and health visitors also have a professional responsibility to highlight any such concerns to the maternity services.

Where a safeguarding concern is identified the case must be discussed with the Safeguarding Midwife. The mother should be informed that there are concerns (if safe to do so) and that the midwife will be sharing information with the safeguarding midwife.
Conclusion
This guideline has been written to support and advise maternity staff how to recognise and manage safeguarding issues in maternity care
Monitoring and Audit
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and Implementation
The policy will be subject to approval at both the Intergrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee.
The policy will be ratified by the Joint Document Management Group and uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
It is the responsilitily of the author to cascade the ratified document to the Intergrated Child and Adult Safeguarding Committee and staff.
The policy will be promoted through relevant internal meetings, and signposted with in safegaurding training.
Equality Impact Assessment
This Policy has been the subject of an Equality Impact Assessment. The output of the assessment demonstrates that no-one, as a consequence of this Policy, is placed at a disadvantage over others.

The MSE Hospitals Group accepts that to accommodate the needs of the increasingly diverse community it serves it must ensure the highest levels of awareness and understanding of equality and diversity amongst its staff.

The MSE Hospitals Group aims to deliver healthcare services that are equitable and are appropriate to each service user's need regardless of age, disability, race, ethnic origin, gender, religion, belief, sexual orientation or domestic circumstances.
Access to services can be affected by a lack of familiarity with health services, the ability to speak English, cultural practices, expectations and other factors.
